bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to [Philip Showalter Hench], September 25, 1949

div1.p: Tate informs [Hench] that he was the medical records clerk at Columbia Barracks during the yellow fever experiments. He claims that Ames was the real hero and yet became the forgotten man because he was simply a contract doctor.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to [Philip Showalter Hench], September 25, 1949
div1.opener:
and JF
Truby
"
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley 3 California
September 25, 1949
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I have heard that you intend publishing a book
dealing with the Yellow Fever experiments in Cuba in 1900-
'01. It intrigues me to think that people are still writing
of that medical discovery of nearly half a century ago.

Of course it was a tremendous event.--The dramatic
solving of a great medical problem, resulting in saving unold
lives, and time and money by eliminating quarrantine, etc.
But one would think that interest would have waned after so
long a time and so much written about it.

I think I have read all the books published on
this subject, and saw the play “Yellow Jack,” and heard sev-
eral radio versions. I found that all but one were written
by people who were not there. I especially had to laugh at
the dramatic version.--Tiled bath room and fancy fixtures!
They should have seen the stark sordiness of the real place!

The only factual account is by Gen Truby. He was
then a Lieutenant, Army Medical Corps and was in charge of
Columbia Barracks Hospital during part of the time the ex-
periments were going on, during the temporary absence of
Captain Stark. I served under both.

But even his account was second-hand, as he had
nothing to do with the experiments other than to detach the
Hospital Corpsmen used in the experiment. Besides he was even
then obsessed with the Regular Army atmosphere and this in-
creased with years of service and promotion. It was closer
to facts than any other book, but yet was more a biography
of Truby than a history of the experiment.--Lots of credit
given to Regular Army Quartermasters, etc. who did nothing
but their duty, but little of the scientific medical aspects
that I heard talked about between Reed, Guerteris, Carroll,
Lazier, Amador, Ames, and other men working with and on the
Board.

No, the inside story of that experiment has not
yet been written. Part of it died with Lazier, and the one
man that could have told it all, Doctor Roger Post Ames, is
dead.

These books interest me because I had a “ringside
seat” during all of it. I was at Pinar del Rio, Cuba in the
Hospital Corps when we were so swamped with deaths from ##

Yellow Fever, which Capt. Godfrey (Reg. Army Doctor) per-
sistently diagnosed as Pernicious Malaria, that Gen. Gorgas
sent Dr. Amador down there to investigate. One doctor there
told me it was Yellow Fever. But he could not do anything
about it because he was only a Contract Doctor. (Not a Reg-
ular)

The post was abandoned and I came to Columbia Bks.
just before the experiments started there, and was medical
record clerk until end of the experiments in 1901. I was as
nearly personally acquainted with every member of the Board
and other doctors as an enlisted man could be with officers.
I was studying for promotion and many of them helped me along.
In course of my duties I saw some of them every day and, of
course heard much talk about the cases. I knew personally
every Hospital Corpsman who took the test (12 of them, of
whom 5 had come with me from P delR.) and talked with them
all before and after the tests.

I would not detract one bota from the heroism of any
one of these men, but in stories I have read, some are rated
higher than others, and generally the rating was wrong.-The
writer was not there, so did not know. In fact, Gen. Truby in
his book, left out one man entirely--Clyde West, Hosp. Corps)

But there would have been no successful experiment if
it had not been for Doctor Ames. He was the one man who did
more for the success of the experiment than any other. This
is my belief, and it would have been known as a fact if Major
Reed had lived longer. (Major Reed was a doctor first, an
army officer second). But where are you going to find any
of this for your book? Like all the other futile writers you
look through War Dept. records and orders or what some Army
doctor wrote. But you won't find the real facts, for Doctor
Ames was a Contract Doctor--not a Regular Army Officer!

Very, very fortunately for his Fever patients, (all of
whom he saved in the experiments and over 50 others) he cared
more for the science of medicine than he did for the Brass
of the Army. And that was unfortunate for him, for he was the
real hero of it all and yet became the forgotten man.

Don't think I'm prejudiced against the Army.--I am an
old Regular Army Man and proud of it. But I think the prac-
tice of medicine is one of the greatest professions in the world,
and I hate to see a man who thinks a little rank and brass
tinsel can add anything to that profession.

I corresponded with Dr. Ame's nurse, Gus. Lambert, who
handled all the experimental cases, and I think he is still
in Chicago. And, believe me, he was in my opinion some hero
himself. He did not have to stick in that horrible place
and alone nurse all those cases (over 8 months). He could
have refused. But I guess he would not let Doctor Ames down.
He was a great Swede I knew him well while there. If you
you want some real information, look him up in Chicago di-
(3)
directory. He really knows more about some phases of that
event than anyone alive.--He should for he saw the really
main part of it from the inside out!

I suppose your book will be like the rest of them,
but I would sure like to read it. I will enclose postal
addressed. Will you kindly name the publishers and date
so I can obtain a copy. Really that is why I wrote this
long crazy letter. Merely intended asking you name of the
publisher, and now look what I've inflicted on you! Its
unforgivable from a perfect stranger, but I hope you will
overlook it. Wishing you great success.
